thread.title: Video: Colts call perhaps worst play in NFL history

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Video: Colts call perhaps worst play in NFL history
text:
Call them the Indianapolis Dolts.
The Colts did something strange in Sunday night’s game against the Patriots. They ran one of those trick plays — an attempt at a fake punt — where everyone lines up wide and they just leave the center and a player to take the snap — but didn’t seem to have much of a plan after that.
“It turned out to be one of the worst failed fakes probably of all time,” Indianapolis punter Pat McAfee said.
 HERE.
AJ Mast/AP What were they thinking? Colt Anderson is tackled a gang of Patriots after the Colts snapped the ball on a bizarre fake punt formation Sunday night.
Trailing 27-21 in the fourth quarter, the Colts brought the punt team out on fourth-and-3 before shifting most of their players near the right sideline. Pagano was hoping to draw the Patriots into a mistake. Instead, receiver Griff Whalen inexplicably snapped the ball to safety Colt Anderson, who was immediately tackled for a 1-yard loss.
“The whole idea there was on fourth-and-3 or less, shift our alignment to where you either catch them misaligned, they try to sub some people in, catch them with 12 men on the field and if you get a certain look, you can make a play,” Colts coach Chuck Pagano said. “Alignment-wise we weren’t lined up correctly, and then a communication problem on the snap. I take responsibility for that.”
Here is the Colts' bizarre formation. Six plays later, Tom Brady, working with a short field from the Colts' 35, found LeGarrette Blount for an 11-yard touchdown to put the Pats up by two scores, 34-21.
Bill Belichick, of course, was ready for it.
“We expected this to be a gadget game,” coach Bill Belichick said. “Their punter ran a sweep against Tennessee a couple weeks ago, so that’s something they’ve done in the past.”
The Colts have had the tricky formation in their playbook for a year, but picked an inopportune time to use it.
“Obviously, it was not ideal,” Colts quarterback Andrew Luck deadpanned.
— With News Wire Services
